captions.text:
When YouTube started demonetising basically
any usage of fudge, I really thought I could cope.

I thought the methadone of saying things
like &quot;noob gobbles&quot; instead would tide me over.

But there really are times when
nothing will do the job but a good hard flip.

So here&#39;s the deal, I&#39;m going to start
saying &quot;flim flam&quot; again, but you&#39;ll only hear it

uncensored in the subscribers version, cause
the extra money means we can tell YouTube to stick

their demonetisation up there. &quot;Nostril!&quot;
As well as meaning you don&#39;t have to put up with

&quot;dastardly&quot;. Sponsors. So head
over to Patreon and &quot;jollywell&quot;. Sign up.
[Intro Music]

Here we bloody go again.
Don&#39;t just rip off the title of

another completely
unrelated game, Lords of the Fallen.
Did we learn nothing from Prey 2016?
Think of the poor confused audience.

You&#39;re gonna make them forget all
about the previous Lords of the Fallen.
There was a previous Lords of the Fallen, Yahtz?
Well, never fucking mind.
I&#39;m sick of complaining about it anyway.

Let&#39;s just add the current year in
parentheses to your title with this hot branding iron
and we can move on.

As I say, Oh No More Lords Of The Fallen 
has almost nothing in common with its namesake,

but for the fact that it&#39;s a soulslike
with a dark fantasy theme, but I repeat myself,

it&#39;s got all the usual souls-like
trappings, you&#39;re an immortal dude on a pilgrimage through

various doomed lands where the locals
have apparently been informed that you&#39;ve been

shagging their collective misses, boss
fights, checkpoints, free healing potion refills,
elevators with buttons in the floor.

But wait a sec, I tried to do that
thing I always do in Dark Souls where after using

a lift I&#39;d send it back and quickly
hop off it so I don&#39;t have to wait for it next

time but I couldn&#39;t do that in Lords of
the Fallen cause the doors closed too quick for
me to hop off.
So, zero stars, better luck next time.

Alright, well that summarises the one
part of my notes where I wrote down bloody lifts
in block capitals, let&#39;s look at the rest.

For the souls-like connoisseur, Lords of
the Fallen plays a pretty straight dark fantasy

with a dash of that Catholic guilt vibe
that Blasphemous does, and just a skip to the weasely

asshole dam with fine praise summary, in
the field of off-brand souls-likes I would describe
it as &quot;okay-ish&quot;.
Which makes it worth talking about, like

discovering a
supermarket-owned brand knock-off cola that&#39;s
actually halfway drinkable.

Obviously it&#39;s not as good as the real
stuff, but it&#39;s pretty amazing that I tolerated it

for as long as I did
before using it as toilet cleaner.

It&#39;s got an interesting suite of bespoke
gimmicks to set it apart, ammo for ranged weapons

refills at checkpoints like your manabar
does, for example, and that&#39;s something in itself,

a souls-like with a viable bow build
that isn&#39;t an optional challenge mode for people

who pride themselves on their
ability to manage the weekly shopping.

Just as well, cause you bloody well need
an accurate ranged option, this game loves ranged
ranged enemies.

If it can bean you in the temple with an
unexpected crossbow bolt just as you&#39;re creeping up for

a backstab, then that&#39;s the day fucking
made as far as Lord of the Fallen&#39;s concerned.

It loves plonking them everywhere in
concealed elevated spots, similar to the relationship

I have with bottles of whiskey
I don&#39;t want the white to know about.

Also the checkpoints are pretty far
apart, but you can use a consumable to create little

mini checkpoints at designated spots like
when you do a little poo in the woods when you

can&#39;t wait for the next rest area, and
if you&#39;re anything like me you&#39;ll keep doing

this not knowing you&#39;re literally around
the corner from the next big checkpoint and get
very cross.

But the big main unique selling point
in Lords of the Fallen&#39;s is dual world gameplay

in a Metroid Prime 2 sort of area, where
you can shift from the living world to the world

of the dead, either by making an
elaborate hand gesture or, you know, getting killed.

And the world of the dead has extra paths
and treasures but also extra enemies and spooky

environment design, although the
level of spookiness tends to be inconsistent.

You&#39;ve got a magic flashlight that lets
you glimpse the dead world version of the current

area in case you want to quick viewing
before you commit to a lease, and sometimes it&#39;s

a whole alternative appearance evoking
Zdzislaw Beksinski throwing a Halloween party in the

Warhammer 40k universe with a gigantic
skeleton looming over everything like it&#39;s had a long

night and mistaken our current
environment for the puke trough, and then sometimes they

just selectively smear some skulls and a
bit of dryer lint about, and sometimes it just

looks exactly the same as the living
world but with the lighting saturation turned down
a notch.

And that communicates what became my
broad impression of Lords of the Fallen a little

bit further this time, that there were
varying levels of could be arsedness in play.

But the dead world does make for an
interesting extra factor to consider, simultaneously expanding

the exploration potential while giving
you a little more wiggle room against the high

difficulty, getting killed isn&#39;t an
immediate failure but more of a getting bumped down

to remedial school where you get one more
chance but you&#39;ve got to start applying yourself

or the pale faceless dudes with the
skinny legs will overtake you in the grade rankings.

But I find these days there&#39;s only one
metric by which I can judge soulslikes, and that&#39;s

how long I can play them before the
soulslike fatigue sets in, and I&#39;d say Lords of the
Fallen Down did quite a bit better than average.

The dual world gimmick gave it a
freshness, ironically, since the dead world looks like

it smells like the inside of a package
of airline pretzels that was forgotten about

in a seat pocket for a year, and the
game doesn&#39;t seem to be doing the usual off-brand

souls-like thing of trying to outdo From
Software when it comes to unreasonable difficulty,
at least not where the boss fights are concerned.

Very few visits from the manor&#39;s father
of the abyss twitchy last second lock-on spaz-out
brigade that took over Elden Ring.

I remember defeating this one hearty lad
who was guarding the objective in the swampy area

and being absolutely astonished that he
didn&#39;t have a second phase, because he&#39;d only taken
like four goes and I still had all my teeth.

It doesn&#39;t hurt that the
game&#39;s generous with NPC support.

Half the boss fights there&#39;s just three
dudes politely lined up outside like schoolkids
waiting for you to pick teams.
Frankly, it made me suspicious.

Yeah, you say you&#39;ll help no strings
attached but how do I know you won&#39;t need help moving
house next week?

Maybe this will turn off all those
twitchy weirdos apparently in the majority who like

it when souls-likes get less and less
reasonable, but I&#39;m hoping to still have working wrists
in my old age so the bosses were fine.

It was all the stuff in
between that eventually wore me down.

I&#39;d say from around the snowy mountain
area onwards the game gets more and more cheeky

about the gauntlets of
enemies it expects you to deal with.

There was one particular hillside path
that took me through like five groups of assholes.

Multiple of those burly shield men who
all need to be carefully danced around unless

you want their shields widening
your bumhole by a factor of two feet.

About three of that one motherfucker who
was an early game boss fight who&#39;s clearly bitter
about not getting a special health bar anymore.

And you can&#39;t just run past them all
because the path is narrow and they&#39;re a dogged bunch.
Especially the dogs.

So it was after banging my head against
that for an afternoon only to discover it was just

a shortcut that didn&#39;t even lead to progress
I soured to Lords of the Ballsack wholeheartedly.

Still it&#39;s definitely a better game than
the first Lords of the Ballsack for what that&#39;s
worth.

Hey, we walked across a room
without breaking our ankles this time.

Although we did trade in the cat&#39;s
litter box and punted the dog through a wall.
[Outro Music]
THIS VIDEO WAS MADE POSSIBLE BY
Closed Captions by @willcblogs
